channel.title: Comments on: Monday Go Meditation: Game 36

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: It's really hard sometimes to gain perspective on where I came from, and I am very grateful to the fact that you and I have a long standing history where you can speak to where I was before. Thanks for reminding me who I was and helping me to restore confidence in myself.
item.content:encoded: It’s really hard sometimes to gain perspective on where I came from, and I am very grateful to the fact that you and I have a long standing history where you can speak to where I was before. Thanks for reminding me who I was and helping me to restore confidence in myself.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Haha. Agreed! It's funny how our games get so violent though. It'll be interesting to see how our next one goes!
item.content:encoded: Haha. Agreed! It’s funny how our games get so violent though. It’ll be interesting to see how our next one goes!

item.title: By: Nate Eagle
item.dc:creator: Nate Eagle
item.description: I think that depends on what kind of go you want to play. If you thrive in a place of greater creativity, it might be good to embrace more unusual openings. You can knock your opponent out of their comfort zone and create opportunities for more complicated fights. I'm not as good at that - I love when I can play with a kind of Lee Chang-ho style smoothness and confidence, each move flowing naturally from a clear understanding of position. Let my opponent fret as my calm opening begins to open up a lead, then let them jump in out of jealousy, create a target, and struggle to live as I develop thickness and territory that will win me the game. Obviously, it's one thing to state this as a goal and another to have the clarity of judgment to play that way.
item.content:encoded:
I think that depends on what kind of go you want to play. If you thrive in a place of greater creativity, it might be good to embrace more unusual openings. You can knock your opponent out of their comfort zone and create opportunities for more complicated fights.
I’m not as good at that – I love when I can play with a kind of Lee Chang-ho style smoothness and confidence, each move flowing naturally from a clear understanding of position. Let my opponent fret as my calm opening begins to open up a lead, then let them jump in out of jealousy, create a target, and struggle to live as I develop thickness and territory that will win me the game. Obviously, it’s one thing to state this as a goal and another to have the clarity of judgment to play that way.

item.title: By: Nate Eagle
item.dc:creator: Nate Eagle
item.description: I remember when you played that opening back when I first met you. I asked about it, and you commented that most people just let you complete the shimari with your next move. I also remember you being an ambitious, whole-board player from early on, something that never came as naturally to me. From my perspective, your core skills are a desire to play your own game (not following) and strong fighting spirit, and that's been true of you since the very first time we played.
item.content:encoded: I remember when you played that opening back when I first met you. I asked about it, and you commented that most people just let you complete the shimari with your next move. I also remember you being an ambitious, whole-board player from early on, something that never came as naturally to me. From my perspective, your core skills are a desire to play your own game (not following) and strong fighting spirit, and that’s been true of you since the very first time we played.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Great advice. Perhaps it is time to try to plunge into the great unknown again. =)
item.content:encoded: Great advice. Perhaps it is time to try to plunge into the great unknown again. =)

item.title: By: Paul
item.dc:creator: Paul
item.description: Nice game and commentary. I think a lot of us forget how adventurous we were in our earlier days: when you don't really know the 4-4 joseki, why not try out the 5-3, or wide pincers with complicated followups, or calm progression? In a lot of our cases, the fear of blundering through unknown joseki and unstudied strategies comes later, when we've got a few nuggets of good knowledge to wield desperately against the world =). It's a good mindset to try to re-cultivate.
item.content:encoded: Nice game and commentary. I think a lot of us forget how adventurous we were in our earlier days: when you don’t really know the 4-4 joseki, why not try out the 5-3, or wide pincers with complicated followups, or calm progression? In a lot of our cases, the fear of blundering through unknown joseki and unstudied strategies comes later, when we’ve got a few nuggets of good knowledge to wield desperately against the world =). It’s a good mindset to try to re-cultivate.
